Package org.bluezoo.gumdrop.http

Class PriorityAwareHTTPConnector

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.bluezoo.gumdrop.Connector
      • org.bluezoo.gumdrop.Server
        • org.bluezoo.gumdrop.http.HTTPServer
          • org.bluezoo.gumdrop.http.PriorityAwareHTTPConnector
  • public class PriorityAwareHTTPConnector
extends HTTPServer
    HTTP connector with HTTP/2 stream priority optimization support.

    This enhanced HTTP connector extends the base HTTPServer with sophisticated stream priority handling capabilities:

    • Priority-based scheduling - Processes high-priority streams first
    • Bandwidth allocation - Distributes resources based on stream weights
    • Starvation prevention - Ensures low-priority streams get fair access
    • Resource optimization - Maximizes throughput for complex applications

    When to Use:

    • Complex web applications with multiple resource types
    • High-traffic servers requiring optimal resource allocation
    • Applications serving mixed content (HTML, CSS, JS, images, APIs)
    • Real-time applications where response ordering matters

    Performance Considerations:

    • Additional memory overhead: ~6-10KB per connection
    • CPU overhead for priority calculations: ~5-10% under load
    • Significant performance gains for multi-resource scenarios
    • May be overkill for simple file servers or single-resource APIs

    Example Usage: 

    
 // Create priority-aware HTTP connector
 PriorityAwareHTTPConnector connector = new PriorityAwareHTTPConnector();
 connector.setPort(8080);
 
 // Optional: Configure priority behaviour
 connector.setPriorityThresholds(0.1, 10); // Min slice: 100ms, Max burst: 10
 
 // Optional: Enable detailed logging
 connector.setPriorityLogging(true);
    Author:
    Chris Burdess
    See Also:
    HTTPServer, StreamPriorityTree, StreamPriorityScheduler

    • Field Detail

      • minLowPriorityTimeSlice

        protected long minLowPriorityTimeSlice
        Minimum time slice for low-priority streams (milliseconds). Low-priority streams that haven't been processed for this duration will be prioritized to prevent starvation.

      • maxHighPriorityBurst

        protected int maxHighPriorityBurst
        Maximum consecutive operations for high-priority streams. After this many consecutive operations, the scheduler will consider lower-priority streams to maintain fairness.

      • priorityLogging

        protected boolean priorityLogging
        Enable detailed priority scheduling logging.

    • Constructor Detail

        public PriorityAwareHTTPConnector()

    • Method Detail

      • getMinLowPriorityTimeSlice

        public long getMinLowPriorityTimeSlice()
        Gets the minimum time slice for low-priority streams.
        Returns:
        time slice in milliseconds

      • setMinLowPriorityTimeSlice

        public void setMinLowPriorityTimeSlice​(long timeSliceMs)
        Sets the minimum time slice for low-priority streams. This prevents starvation by ensuring low-priority streams get processing time after being idle for the specified duration.
        Parameters:
        timeSliceMs - time slice in milliseconds (minimum: 10ms)

      • getMaxHighPriorityBurst

        public int getMaxHighPriorityBurst()
        Gets the maximum burst size for high-priority streams.
        Returns:
        maximum consecutive high-priority operations

      • setMaxHighPriorityBurst

        public void setMaxHighPriorityBurst​(int burstSize)
        Sets the maximum burst size for high-priority streams. This limits how many consecutive operations high-priority streams can perform before yielding to lower-priority streams.
        Parameters:
        burstSize - maximum consecutive operations (minimum: 1)

      • isPriorityLogging

        public boolean isPriorityLogging()
        Checks if detailed priority logging is enabled.
        Returns:
        true if priority logging is enabled

      • setPriorityLogging

        public void setPriorityLogging​(boolean enabled)
        Enables or disables detailed priority scheduling logging. When enabled, logs priority decisions, resource allocations, and scheduling statistics at FINE level.
        Parameters:
        enabled - true to enable detailed logging

      • setPriorityThresholds

        public void setPriorityThresholds​(long minTimeSliceMs,
                                  int maxBurstSize)
        Configures priority thresholds in a single call.
        Parameters:
        minTimeSliceMs - minimum time slice for low-priority streams
        maxBurstSize - maximum consecutive high-priority operations
